annotation.TEXT: Ice Capades was an entertainment company that created traveling theatrical productions centered around ice skating. It toured from 1940-95.
The Genie Co. has been making automatic garage door openers since 1954.
With annotations provided by The Annotated MST website.
Lt. Commander Data, played by Brent Spiner, was the pale-skinned android crew member on Star Trek: The Next Generation.
In five decades, actor Gene Hackman was nominated for five Oscars; he won twice, for The French Connection and Unforgiven.
The saying “hair of the dog that bit you,” meaning drink to cure a hangover, comes from the belief that you could cure rabies with a potion containing fur from the rabid dog.
The longtime ad slogan of tool manufacturer Stanley Works, now Stanley Black & Decker, is “Stanley helps you do things right.”
Bela Lugosi found himself limited to horror films thanks to his Hungarian accent—and to typecasting from his first major part, Dracula.
Tupperware containers are traditionally sold at “Tupperware parties.” The single mom who came up with the strategy was made Tupperware’s VP of marketing.
The height requirements on theme park rides are for safety reasons: riders must fit the restraints properly or risk being thrown from the ride.
Actress Cloris Leachman has appeared in memorable roles both on TV (The Mary Tyler Moore Show and Phyllis) and in film (Young Frankenstein).
Gold’n Plump is a Minnesota-based poultry processor founded in 1926. The symbol Joel is pointing to is the old MPAA logo, administrators of the oft-criticized film ratings system.
“Flak” is a term for anti-aircraft fire, from the German word “Fliegerabwehrkanonen.” By the ‘60s it had come to metaphorically mean “criticism.”
Burgess Meredith was Rocky’s trainer in the Sylvester Stallone films and played the Penguin in the campy ‘60s TV show Batman.
Dr. Denton’s sleeper pajamas were designed by Whitney Denton (not a doctor—they added “Dr.” to the name to imply educated endorsement).
The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade is well known for its balloons of popular characters, but the majestic procession was downsized after a series of accidents and injuries in the ‘90s.
In 2008, Leachman became the oldest competitor on Dancing with the Stars. She was 82 at the time.
The song “Good Old Days,” written by Leroy Shield, was first used in the 1930 Our Gang short Teacher’s Pet.
A play on George Romero’s 1968 zombie classic Night of the Living Dead.
Invented in 1940, “walkie-talkie” originally referred only to the backpack-mounted model. The handheld transceivers were called “handie-talkies.”
Republic Pictures also made a bunch of Zorro and Lone Ranger serials, as well as the first superhero films ever made.
Let us know if we missed any references!
Little person actor Hervé Villechaize became famous for the line “De plane! De plane!” on the TV show Fantasy Island.
Actor Abe Vigoda was best known for playing Sergeant Phil Fish on the TV series Barney Miller and its spinoff, Fish.
The Corpse Vanishes: Fully annotated by The Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
Mister Salty was a brand of thin pretzel sticks made by Nabisco from the ‘60s-‘80s. The mascot was a twisted pretzel snack in a sailor’s cap.
There were multiple stun settings, which led to disorientation at the lowest and prolonged unconsciousness at the highest.
A line from the theme song to the TV sitcom Gilligan’s Island.
“The Teapot Song” was written in 1939 by George Harold Sanders and Clarence Z. Kelley. Kelley ran a dance school for children and used it to teach his younger students pantomime.
Life Savers were first made in 1912 by Ohioan Clarence Crane to provide a treat that could withstand heat better than chocolate. The first available flavor was peppermint.
Leachman won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar in 1971 for her role in The Last Picture Show.
“Harelip, harelip” is the punch line to a joke about a lonely guy who wants to meet women but is self-conscious about his wooden eye.
Discover the meaning behind every reference.
“It’s not just for breakfast anymore” is a slogan for the Florida Orange Juice Growers Association.
Although drivers used to be told to keep their hands at 10 o’clock and 2 o’clock on the steering wheel, since airbags became common, this has changed to either 9 and 3 or 8 and 4.
“Carry Me Back to Old Virginny” was written by African-American musician James Bland in 1878. It was Virginia’s state song until 1997, when it was retired due to its lyrics (i.e., the word “darkey”).
“Sleeper hold” is the name given to a type of chokehold, most often used in wrestling, that knocks out the opponent.
The Addams Family house first appeared in Charles Addams’ cartoons, where it was a condemned wreck. In the ‘60s TV series, it was more of a mansion, located at 0001 Cemetery Lane.
“The only thing we have to fear is fear itself” is a famous line from President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s first inaugural speech in March 1933.
The Little Rascals were a syndicated TV series about a group of neighborhood kids; producer Hal Roach recycled them from his theatrical series of Our Gang film shorts.
The University of Notre Dame’s fight song is titled “Victory March.” It was written in 1908 by brothers and alumni Michael and John Shea.
The fabric’s name derives from the fiber’s elasticity: “Spandex” is an anagram of “expands.”
Gloomy Gus was originally a character in the comic strip “Happy Hooligan”; USC football coach Elmer Henderson was nicknamed “Gloomy Gus” because he badmouthed the team’s prospects before every game.
An imitation of British hairstylist Vidal Sassoon, who brought back the bob in the ‘60s and sold his own line of hair care products in the ‘70s & ‘80s, often appearing in ads.
A line from the 1983 hit single “Legs” by ZZ Top.
Ian Fleming got the name of his iconic spy character from the author of a book called Birds of the West Indies (he was an enthusiastic birdwatcher).
Thanks for watching this fully-annotated presentation of The Corpse Vanishes.
Tyco Toys, famous for its H-O scale trains, was founded by John Tyler in 1926 (the name is a contraction of “Tyler Company”).
Another FDR quote, this one from his Dec. 8, 1941, address to Congress asking for a declaration of war, the day after Japan’s attack on Pearl Harbor.
A really terrible imitation of Ed Sullivan, host of the TV variety show The Ed Sullivan Show.
Dr. Scholl’s is a foot care brand started in 1906 by podiatrist William Scholl. Dr Pepper is a soft drink manufactured by the Dr Pepper/Seven Up corporation. It was first introduced in 1885.
This was one of the ruses used by the land shark on SNL. Candygram is a service Western Union began offering in the ‘60s that sends its messages along with a box of chocolates.
Thrush is a maker of automotive parts, primarily mufflers. They’ve been in business since 1966.
A reference to C.S. Lewis’s 1950 allegorical fantasy novel The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.
The first season of SNL ran a series of skits that parodied the film Jaws, in which Chevy Chase in a shark suit (the “land shark”) would con his way into people’s apartments and eat them.
Lugosi never said “Bleh!” as Dracula. This appears to originate with comedian Gabriel Dell, who performed a popular Dracula impersonation on The Steve Allen Show.
Soapbox racers were first made in the early ‘30s from things like orange crates and tin. Nowadays the cars are made from plastic and fiberglass.
Marketing for Alfred Hitchcock’s 1960 classic thriller Psycho used the slogan “No one … BUT NO ONE … will be admitted to the theatre after the start of each performance!”
Wallace Fox directed 84 films during his career, including this and a few entries in the “East Side Kids” series.
The phaser energy weapons used on Star Trek could be set either to stun or to kill.
In a TV ad from the ‘60s, a cigarette girl like this one circulated through a swank nightclub, cooing, “Cigars, cigarettes, Tiparillos?” Tiparillos were short, thin cigars with plastic tips.
A corruption of the song “Get Me to the Church on Time” from the musical My Fair Lady. (It’s supposed to be “married,” not “buried.”)
In the original Grimms’ fairy tale, Snow White’s 7 dwarves are unnamed. Other names considered for the Disney version: Jumpy, Hickey, Baldy, Gabby, Lazy, Tubby, and Burpy.
Despite urban legend, the candy was not designed with a hole in the center to save the lives of choking children. Instead, they were meant to resemble lifebuoys.
A parody of a line spoken by the second witch in William Shakespeare’s play Macbeth: “By the pricking of my thumbs, Something wicked this way comes.”
Brought to you by the Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
“They wake with the worst breath of the day” is a line from a series of Scope mouthwash ads that ran in the ‘70s.
“She’s got a ticket to ride, and she don’t care” is a line from the 1965 Beatles hit “Ticket to Ride.”
The transparent polymer Saran was invented in 1933 and originally used as a spray to weatherproof fighter planes. Saran Wrap came along in 1949.
Disney theme parks used to have “E tickets” or “E coupons” that gave ticket holders access to the newest or most popular attractions. The system was abandoned in 1982.
Also known as the floating finger illusion, this is caused by your brain trying to force two overlapping images from your eyes to correspond, and getting it wrong.
Das Boot (The Boat) is a 1981 film about the crew of a German U-boat during WWII.
A line from the Monty Python skit “Cosmetic Surgery,” exclaimed joyously by Graham Chapman after John Cleese invites him to come on a romantic camping holiday.
William Shakespeare’s play Much Ado About Nothing was written in 1598. It is considered among his best comedies.
A paraphrased line from the 1975 film Jaws, spoken by Richard Dreyfuss: “This was no boat accident!”
Another land shark excuse.
Did we miss any? Tell us in the comments!
Mr. Peanut is the aristocratic ad mascot of Planters snack foods. He was created by a schoolboy for a 1916 contest, although an artist later added the top hat, monocle, and cane.
“Cappy Dick’s Young Hobby Club” was a comic strip created by Robert Cleveland that featured puzzles, riddles, and games for children.
Carnival Story’s tag line was “The story of a woman’s shame!” It’s a film about a female pickpocket who becomes ensnared in the machinations of a carnival barker.
Mr. Bubble, the ad mascot for the kids’ bubble bath, debuted in the late ‘60s and has been used, almost unchanged, ever since.
The princess phone was introduced in 1959. It was intended to be kept in the bedroom, and to this end, it had a lighted dial that could be seen in the dark.
Curly was famous for his wide assortment of peculiar noises and sound effects.
Lee Harvey Oswald assassinated President John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963. He was arrested in a movie theater about an hour later.
Stanley no longer makes garage door openers; they sold the rights to a company that then filed for bankruptcy in 2001.
Little person actor Billy Barty played the imp in MST3K Episode 806, The Undead. The actor here is Angelo Rossitto, who also appeared in Tod Browning’s classic Freaks.
Lawn darts (aka javelin darts or jarts) were large metal-weighted darts with plastic fins. Due to safety concerns (one girl died; thousands were injured), the US banned them in 1988.
Camille is a Parisian courtesan, created by Alexandre Dumas and later adapted for stage and screen, who nobly dies of consumption for the good of her aristocratic lover.
In this variation on the classic game of freeze tag, a player becomes “unfrozen” when another player touches them and says the title of a TV show.
“The Dance of the Cuckoos,” composed by Marvin Hatley, was used as the theme song for most of the comedy duos’ films.
Cadillac Ranch is an art installation in Amarillo, TX: 10 Cadillacs half-buried with their hoods in the ground and set at the same angle as the slope of the Great Pyramid of Giza.
Did we miss a reference? Be sure to let us know in the comments!
Leachman appeared in three Mel Brooks comedies: Young Frankenstein, High Anxiety, and History of the World Part I.
Now it's time to sit back and enjoy…the fully-annotated Corpse Vanishes!
Singer/actor Nelson Eddy made a string of hit films with Jeanette MacDonald in the ‘30s and ‘40s. His songs include “Ah! Sweet Mystery of Life” and “Indian Love Call.”
A parody of the theme song to the TV sitcom Mister Ed, about a talking horse. The tune is based on a song by 19th-century composer Emile Waldteufel.
Officers Francis “Ponch” Poncherello (Erik Estrada) and Jonathan Baker (Larry Wilcox) were the two motorcycle cops on the TV series CHiPs.
A likely reference to the 1975 best-selling book Dress for Success by John T. Molloy.
You can make a shadow puppet of 16th president Abraham Lincoln, if you’re interested. You can also make JFK, Fidel Castro, and Charles De Gaulle.
In entertainment, the Cossack ethnic group native to the Ukraine and southern Russia is remembered for their crouched, high-kicking dance, called the hopak.
An imitation of Curly Howard (b. Jerome Lester Horwitz) of the Three Stooges.
Designed in 1898, the Michelin Man is intended to look as if he is made from a stack of tires. His given name is Bibendum, which first appeared in 1908.
An extended parody of Devo’s 1980 hit single “Whip It.”
Lava soap is a heavy-duty hand cleaner created in 1893. It contains ground pumice to act as an abrasive in cleaning the skin.
Variants of this phrase originated with title cards used in silent films. In westerns, it was often “Meanwhile, back at the ranch ...”
The Wham-O Magic Window was a ‘70s novelty: a plastic oval containing tiny white and colored crystals that flowed when turned without ever getting mixed together.
General Foods International Coffees is a line of flavored instant coffee first released in the ‘70s.
An imitation of the “Necktie Killer,” played by Barry Foster, in the Alfred Hitchcock film Frenzy.
“I have a bad feeling about this” is a phrase that has appeared (or some variation) in every Star Wars film thus far.
Brookdale Center was a shopping mall in suburban Minneapolis. It opened in 1962 and closed in 2010 after years of decline.
The first Meals on Wheels sprang up to deliver food in the UK during WWII, when many people lost their homes to German bombing raids.
In an ‘80s ad for the Time-Life book series The Vietnam Experience, a boy at the Vietnam Memorial in Washington, DC, asks his father this question.
A line from Warren Zevon’s 1978 hit song “Werewolves of London.”
Ads for Yuban coffee in the ‘70s showed insecure wives who didn’t understand why their husbands never wanted a second cup of coffee at home.
Shecky Greene is a comedian known for his nightclub standup act, mostly in Las Vegas.
Created in Denmark during WWII for the Esso oil company, Drip and Drop were mascots shaped like oil drops. Drip (aka Mr. Drip) came to the US in 1958 and was used for several years.
Variants of the “Three Blind Mice” tune were frequently used in Three Stooges shorts.
Metamorphosis is an illusion made famous by Harry Houdini: the assistant is chained in a locked trunk. The magician lifts a curtain in front of him, and the two seem to instantly trade places.
